headline.print_headline: NIH Takes Another Shot at Studying Environment, Child Health
headline.main: NIH Takes Another Shot at Studying Environment, Child Health

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Institutes of Health is launching a new project to help unravel how early-in-life environmental exposures may affect autism, obesity and certain other childhood disorders. It's a second shot at tackling those important questions, after a more ambitious research attempt failed.

headline.print_headline: Grocery Chains Leave Food Deserts Barren, AP Analysis Finds
headline.main: Grocery Chains Leave Food Deserts Barren, AP Analysis Finds

docs.lead_paragraph: As part of Michelle Obama's healthy eating initiative, a group of major food retailers promised in 2011 to open or expand 1,500 grocery or convenience stores in and around neighborhoods with no supermarkets by 2016. By their own count, they're far short.

headline.print_headline: The Defense of Sugary Soda That Fizzled
headline.main: A Defense of Sugary Soda That Fizzled for Coke

docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes fact that Coca-Cola Company has been forced to back away from Global Energy Balance Network, nonprofit group it helped found that sought to emphasize exercise as best way to combat obesity; notes goal was essentially marketing campaign under veneer of scientific research.
docs.lead_paragraph: The beverage company tried to put a scientific veneer on what amounted to a marketing campaign.
docs.snippet: The beverage company tried to put a scientific veneer on what amounted to a marketing campaign.

headline.print_headline: Groups Ask Mexico to Pull Coca-Cola Ad on Indigenous
headline.main: Groups Ask Mexico to Pull Coca-Cola Ad on Indigenous

docs.lead_paragraph: It looks like many Coca-Cola ads with long-haired, do-gooder hipsters teaching the world to sing or sharing a Coke and a smile.

headline.main: Research Group Funded by Coca-Cola to Disband

docs.abstract: Public health authorities said that the group’s mission was to play down the link between soft drinks and obesity.
docs.snippet: Public health authorities said that the group’s mission was to play down the link between soft drinks and obesity.

headline.print_headline: Group Funded by Coke to Fight Obesity Disbanding
headline.main: Group Funded by Coke to Fight Obesity Disbanding

docs.lead_paragraph: A nonprofit funded by the Coca-Cola Co. to combat obesity is disbanding following revelations about the beverage maker's involvement with the group.

headline.print_headline: In Major Shift, Diabetes Cases Start to Decline
headline.main: New Diabetes Cases, at Long Last, Begin to Fall in the United States

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports rate of new diabetes cases in United States fell by about one fifth from 2008 to 2014; decline follows decades of nonstop increase; cases fell to 1.4 million in 2014 from 1.7 million in 2008; evidence points to better eating habits.
docs.lead_paragraph: The rate of new cases from 2008 to 2014 declined by about one-fifth, a possible indication that Americans are getting a little healthier.
docs.snippet: The rate of new cases from 2008 to 2014 declined by about one-fifth, a possible indication that Americans are getting a little healthier.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

headline.print_headline: More Menus Have Calorie Counts, Yet Obesity Rates Remain High
headline.main: The Failure of Calorie Counts on Menus

byline.contributor: Aaron E. Carroll is a professor of pediatrics at Indiana University School of Medicine. He blogs on health research and policy at The Incidental Economist, and you can follow him on Twitter at @aaronecarroll.

docs.abstract: The Upshot; studies show that labels showing calorie counts in fast food restaurants and supermarkets do little to reduce amount of calories people consume; some other, simpler interventions, however, hold promise.
docs.lead_paragraph: It turns out that knowing calorie amounts is not necessarily going to change what people eat. What else might work better?
docs.snippet: It turns out that knowing calorie amounts is not necessarily going to change what people eat. What else might work better?
